title: Short Notes
html:
Short Notes of CS201

üöÄ Welcome to CS201 ‚Äì Introduction to Programming

üéØ CS201 is your first step into the exciting world of programming! It‚Äôs all about understanding the fundamental concepts that make software work, like problem-solving, logic, and how computers execute instructions. Don't worry if it sounds complex; we'll break it down into easy, digestible pieces. ÔøΩ

This subject focuses on building a strong foundation in programming, which is crucial for any computer science student. We'll cover everything from basic definitions to writing your first C++ programs. üìö

So, champ üèÜ‚Äîtie your seatbelt, embrace the logic, and get ready to code your way through CS201. Let‚Äôs do this together! üí™üî•

Lecture No. 1: What is Programming

Summary

  • What is programming
  • Why programming is important
  • What skills are needed
  • Develop a basic recipe for writing programs
  • Points to remember

What is Programming?

A program is a precise sequence of steps to solve a particular problem. It means having a complete set of activities to be performed in a specific order to achieve a given purpose.

Programming a computer simply means telling it what to do. Everything else involves the specific mechanisms for doing so.

Why Programming is Important?

Learning to program develops analytical and problem-solving abilities. It is a creative activity that allows us to express abstract ideas. It's more than a vocational skill; it teaches critical reading, analytical thinking, and creative synthesis, valuable in all professions.

Skills Needed for Programming

  • Paying attention to detail: A single mistake can break the entire program. Logic and precision are paramount.
  • Think about reusability: Write code that can be used again for similar or related problems.
  • Think about good user interface: Design programs that are easy for users to understand and use, assuming they are not computer literate.
  • Understand that computers are stupid: Computers follow instructions exactly; they don't infer meaning. Instructions must be explicit.
  • Comment the code liberally: Explain the program's functioning for other programmers and your future self. Comments are ignored by the compiler.

Program Design Recipe

To design programs effectively, follow a recipe:

  1. Analyze the problem statement: Understand the problem thoroughly, expressed typically as a word problem.
  2. Express its essence: Abstractly and with examples.
  3. Formulate statements and comments: Use a precise language (e.g., pseudocode, flowcharts).
  4. Evaluate and revise: Test and check the program, repeating the process if changes are needed.
  5. Pay attention to detail: Crucial throughout the entire process.
Step Description
Analysis Understand inputs, outputs, constants, and break into functional units.
Design Detailed planning, including data structures (e.g., arrays), and module breakdown.
Implementation Translate pseudocode/flowchart into code, compile, and run.
Testing & Revision Verify functionality, fix bugs, and refine the solution.

Points to Remember

  • Don't assume knowledge on the part of the users.
  • User Interface should be friendly and self-explanatory.
  • Don't forget to comment the code.
  • PAY ATTENTION TO DETAIL.
  • Program, program, and program ‚Äî this includes the entire process of design and development, not just coding.

Lecture No. 2: Software Categories & History of C Language

Summary

  • Software Categories (System Software, Application Software)
  • History of C language
  • Development Environment of 'C'

Software Categories

Software is broadly categorized into two main types:

  1. System Software: Controls the computer hardware and manages other programs.
  2. Application Software: Designed for end-users to perform specific tasks.

System Software Sub-categories:

  • Operating System (OS): Manages all other programs, controlling hardware resources (memory, CPU, disk space, peripherals). Example: Windows, macOS, Linux.
  • Device Drivers: Software enabling communication between devices (keyboard, mouse, printer) and the computer. E.g., TWAIN Drivers for scanners.
  • Utility Software: Programs performing specific tasks related to system resource management. E.g., Disk Compression, Disk Defragmentation. Compilers and interpreters also fall here.

Application Software:

Programs or groups of programs designed for end-users. Examples: Word processing, accounting software, GPS systems, games.

History of C Language

  • Developed in the late 60s and early 70s at Bell Laboratories.
  • Evolved from BCPL (1967 by Martin Richards) and B (1970 by Ken Thompson).
  • Dennis Ritchie developed C, incorporating features from BCPL and B while adding data typing.
  • C became widely known as the development language for the UNIX operating system, which was largely written in C.
  • Its power allows direct manipulation of computer hardware.
  • Due to widespread use and variations, ANSI (1983) and ISO (1989) standardized C to ensure machine-independent definition.

Tools of the Trade (Development Environment of 'C')

Programmers use various tools throughout the program's life cycle:

  • Editors: Used for writing code (plain text editors are preferred over word processors for simplicity).
  • Compiler & Interpreter: Translators that convert human-readable code into machine language (0s and 1s).
    • Interpreter: Translates line by line, provides immediate error feedback, but executes slower.
    • Compiler: Translates the entire program at once, produces executable code only if syntax is correct, executes faster. (Used in CS201)
  • Debugger: Tool for finding and correcting logical errors by allowing control over program execution (e.g., pausing, checking variable values).
  • Linker: Combines compiled code with necessary routines and functions from libraries to create a standalone executable program.
  • Loader: Loads the executable program into memory and instructs the processor to begin execution (starting from `main` function).

Lecture No. 3: First C Program, Variables, Data Types & Operators

Summary

  • First C Program structure
  • Variables
  • Data Types (int, short, long, float, double, char)
  • Arithmetic Operators
  • Precedence of Operators
  • Tips for coding

First C Program

Let's examine the basic structure of a C++ program: 

#include <iostream.h>
main()
{
  cout << "Welcome to Virtual University of Pakistan";
}
  • #include <iostream.h>: A pre-processor directive. It tells the compiler to include the contents of iostream.h, which contains code for input/output operations (like displaying text on screen).
  • main(): The special function where program execution begins. Every C++ program must have a main() function. The parentheses () indicate it's a function.
  • { }: Curly braces define a block of statements. All code within `main()` must be enclosed in these braces.
  • cout << "Welcome to Virtual University of Pakistan";: This statement prints the text enclosed in double quotes to the console. `cout` is the output stream, and `<<` indicates data direction (towards `cout`).
  • ;: A semicolon marks the end of a statement in C++. Missing it causes a syntax error.

Variables

Variables are named locations in memory for storing data. Think of them as labeled boxes where you can put different values at different times. Each variable has a:

  • Name: How you refer to the memory location. Must start with a character or underscore (avoid underscore for user-defined names).
  • Type: Defines what kind of data it can hold (e.g., whole numbers, decimal numbers, characters).
  • Size: How much memory it occupies (depends on data type, machine, and compiler).
  • Value: The actual data stored in the memory location.

Assignment Operator (=)

In C++, the equal sign `(=)` is the assignment operator. It takes the value on the right-hand side and stores it into the variable on the left-hand side. 

x = 5;       // Assigns value 5 to variable x
x = 10 + 5;  // Assigns result of (10 + 5) to x
x = x + 1;   // Increments the value of x by 1 (common in C++)

Important: In C++, `x = x + 1` is valid; it means "take the current value of x, add 1 to it, and store the new result back into x.

short-notes-sub-heading">Data Types

A variable's data type determines its size in memory and how `cout` displays its value. Data types are reserved words and cannot be used as variable names.

Whole Numbers:

  • int: Used for integers. Typically 4 bytes (32 bits), stores a wide range of whole numbers. Declared as `int i;`.
  • short: Used for smaller integers. Typically 2 bytes, range from -32768 to 32767. Useful for memory optimization when values are known to be small (e.g., `short age;`).
  • long: Used for very large integers, typically 4 or 8 bytes depending on system.

Real Numbers (Floating-Point Numbers):

  • float: Used for real numbers with decimal points. Typically 4 bytes, provides single-precision floating-point values.
  • double: Used for larger or more precise real numbers. Typically 8 bytes, provides double-precision floating-point values.

Characters:

  • char: Used for storing single characters. Typically 1 byte. Character values are assigned using single quotes, e.g., `char letter = 'a';`.

Arithmetic Operators

C++ provides standard arithmetic operators:

Arithmetic Operation Operator Algebraic Expression C++ Expression
Addition + $x + y$ x + y
Subtraction - $x - y$ x - y
Multiplication * $xy$ x * y
Division / $x \div y$, $x / y$ x / y
Modulus (Remainder) % $x \pmod y$ x % y
  • Integer Division: When both operands are integers, ` / ` yields an integer result, truncating any fractional part (e.g., `5 / 2` results in `2`). Use `float` or `double` for non-integer division.
  • Modulus (`%`): Returns the remainder of an integer division. Only works with integer operands (e.g., `5 % 2` results in `1`).

Precedence of Operators

Operators are evaluated in a specific order:

Operators Operations Precedence (Order of Evaluation)
() Parentheses Evaluated first. Innermost parentheses evaluated first.
*, /, % Multiplication, Division, Modulus Evaluated second. If several, evaluated from left to right.
+, - Addition, Subtraction Evaluated last. If several, evaluated from left to right.

Example: `10 + 10 * 5` results in `60` (10 * 5 first, then +). `(10 + 10) * 5` results in `100`.

Tips for C++ Coding

  • Use spaces in code for readability.
  • Reserved words cannot be used as variable names.
  • Every C++ program needs a main() function as the starting point.
  • Write one statement per line for clarity.
  • Type parentheses `()` and braces `{}` in pairs to avoid syntax errors.
  • Use parentheses for clarification in arithmetic expressions.
  • Don't forget semicolon at the end of each statement.
  • C++ is case-sensitive (`x` and `X` are different variables).

Lecture No. 4: Sample Programs, Expressions & Operators in Depth

Summary

  • Sample Program: Calculate average age of 10 students
  • cin for input
  • Examples of Expressions
  • Use of Modulus (`%`) and Division (`/`) operators for digit extraction
  • Tips for program design

Sample Program: Calculate Average Age

Problem Statement: Calculate the average age of a class of ten students. Prompt the user to enter the age of each student.

Solution Analysis:

  • Declare ten int variables for ages (e.g., `age1, age2, ..., age10`).
  • Declare `TotalAge` (int) and `AverageAge` (int or float/double for precise results).
  • Use `cout` to prompt the user for input. Be clear and specific (e.g., "Please enter the age of student 1 (whole number only):").
  • Use `cin` to read input from the user. `cin >> variableName;` reads input and assigns it to the variable. It stops execution until the user enters data and presses Enter.
  • `cin` can only take one variable after `>>`; expressions like `cin >> x + y;` are invalid.
  • Sum all ages into `TotalAge`.
  • Calculate `AverageAge = TotalAge / 10;`. Remember integer division truncates.
  • Display the result using `cout`.

Key Input/Output Concepts:

  • cout <<

.
  • Input/Output: Parallelogram shape (for `cin` and `cout` operations).
  • Continuation (Connector): Circle shape (used to connect parts of a flowchart on different pages or sections).

    • if/else Structure

    The `if/else` structure allows a programmer to specify an alternative block of code to be executed when the `if` condition is false. 

    if ( condition )
{
  statement(s) for true condition;
}
else
{
  statement(s) for false condition;
}
    • If `condition` is `true`, the `if` block executes.
    • If `condition` is `false`, the `else` block executes.
    • This structure is useful for handling two mutually exclusive outcomes. Ensure all possible cases are covered (e.g., for `A > B`, `else` covers `A < B` and `A == B`).

    Logical Operators

    Used to combine multiple conditions for complex decisions.

    Operator Meaning Description
    && Logical AND Both expressions must be `true` for the combined condition to be `true`. (e.g., `age > 18 && height > 6`)
    || Logical OR At least one expression must be `true` for the combined condition to be `true`. (e.g., `degree ==

`) ! Logical NOT Reverses the boolean meaning of a condition. (e.g., `! (age > 18)` is true if `age` is NOT greater than `18`). Unary operator.

Truth Table for Logical AND (&&):

Expression 1 Expression 2 Expression 1 && Expression 2
True True True
True False False
False True False
False False False

Truth Table for Logical OR (||):

Expression 1 Expression 2 Expression 1 || Expression 2
True True True
True False True
False True True
False False False

Truth Table for Logical NOT (!):

Expression !Expression
True False
False True

Sample Program: Discount Calculation

Problem Statement: A shopkeeper offers 10% discount on all bills, but 15% if the bill amount is greater than 5000. Write a C++ program to calculate the payable amount.

Solution Analysis:

  • Declare `amount`, `discount`, `netPayable` as `double` (or `float`) to handle decimals. Initialize them to 0.
  • Prompt user for `amount` using `cin`.
  • Use an `if/else` statement to determine discount:
    • If `amount > 5000`, apply 15% discount.
    • Else (if `amount <= 5000`), apply 10% discount.
  • Calculate `discount = amount * (percentage / 100.0);`. Use `10.0` or `15.0` to ensure floating-point division.
  • `netPayable = amount - discount;`.
  • Display `discount` and `netPayable`.

Complete Program Example: Discount Calculation

/* This program calculates the discount amount for a customer. As different discount
percentage applies on different amount so program is using if statement for deciding
which discount is applicable and display the result. */
#include <iostream.h>
main ()
{
  double amount, discount, netPayable;
  amount = 0;
  netPayable = 0;
  discount = 0;

  // prompt the user to enter the bill amount
  cout << "Please enter the amount of the bill ";
  cin >> amount;

  //test the conditions and calculate net payable
  if ( amount > 5000 )
  {
    //calculate amount at 15 % discount
    discount = amount * (15.0 / 100);
    netPayable = amount - discount;
    cout << "The discount at the rate 15 % is Rupees " << discount << endl;
    cout << "The payable amount is Rupees " << netPayable;
  }
  else
  {
    // calculate amount at 10 % discount
    discount = amount * (10.0 / 100);
    netPayable = amount - discount;
    cout << "The discount at the rate 10 % is Rupees " << discount << endl;
    cout << "The payable amount is Rupees " << netPayable;
  }
}

Sample Output:
Please enter the amount of the bill 6500
The discount at the rate 15 % is Rupees 975
The payable amount is Rupees 5525

Tips for Conditional Statements

  • Always put the braces `{}` in an `if/else` structure, even if only one statement.
  • Type the beginning and ending braces before typing inside them.
  • Indent both body statements of an `if` and `else` structure.
  • Be careful while combining conditions with logical operators (understand precedence).
  • Use `if/else` structure instead of multiple single `if` statements when handling mutually exclusive conditions.

Lecture No. 6: Repetition Structure (Loops) & Overflow

Summary

  • Repetition Structure (Loop) - `while` loop
  • Overflow Condition
  • Sample Programs
  • Infinite Loop
  • Properties of `while` loop
  • Flow Chart for `while` loop
  • Tips

Repetition Structure (Loop)

Repetition, or looping, is crucial in programming for performing tasks multiple times. For example, processing payroll for all employees or summing a series of numbers.

The `while` Loop Structure:

The `while` loop repeatedly executes a block of statements as long as a specified condition (logical expression) remains true. `while` is a reserved keyword. 

while ( Logical Expression ) {
  statement1;
  statement2;
  // ...
}
  • The `Logical Expression` contains relational or logical operators and must evaluate to `true` or `false`.
  • Statements inside the loop block (`{}`) are executed repeatedly as long as the expression is `true`.
  • When the expression becomes `false`, the loop terminates, and the program continues with the statement immediately after the loop block.
  • Always use curly braces `{}` with `while` loops, even for single statements, for clarity and to prevent logical errors. Indentation is also key for readability.

Sample Problem: Sum of First 1000 Integers

Problem: Calculate the sum of the first 1000 whole numbers (1 to 1000).

Solution Approach with `while` loop:

  • Initialize a variable `sum` to `0` (e.g., `int sum = 0;`).
  • Initialize a counter variable, say `number`, to `1` (e.g., `int number = 1;`). This will be our current integer.
  • Set up a `while` loop: `while (number <= 1000)`.
  • Inside the loop:
    • Add the current `number` to `sum`: `sum = sum + number;` (or `sum += number;`).
    • Increment `number`: `number = number + 1;` (or `number++;`). This is crucial to eventually make the loop condition false and avoid an infinite loop.
  • After the loop, display the final `sum`.

Flowchart for `while` Loop:

Overflow Condition

An overflow occurs when an arithmetic operation attempts to create a numeric value that is outside of the range that can be represented by the data type used. For instance, if `int` can only hold up to 32767 and you try to store 32768, an overflow will occur, leading to incorrect results (e.g., the number

to the minimum negative value).

Infinite Loop

An infinite loop occurs when the condition for a loop never becomes false, causing the loop to run indefinitely. This usually happens if the variable controlling the loop is not updated correctly inside the loop. 

int count = 1;
while (count <= 5) {
  cout << "Hello";
  // Missing: count++; -- This would lead to an infinite loop
}

Properties of `while` Loop

  • Entry-controlled loop: The condition is checked at the beginning of each iteration.
  • Zero or more iterations: If the condition is initially false, the loop body will not execute even once.
  • Requires explicit update of the condition variable within the loop body.

Tips for Loops

  • Always ensure the loop condition will eventually become false to avoid infinite loops.
  • Initialize loop control variables properly before the loop.
  • Update loop control variables correctly within the loop body.
  • Use meaningful variable names for loop counters and accumulators.
  • Consider using `long` data type for sums that might exceed `int` capacity to prevent overflow.
